articles.title: I tested 30 smart locks, and these are the best
articles.summary: A recent review highlights the Kwikset Halo Select smart lock as a top choice for enhancing home security and convenience, featuring multiple access methods, including app control and auto-unlock capabilities. This is significant as it demonstrates the growing integration of smart locks with home automation systems, offering users greater control and peace of mind. Key implications include the potential for improved compatibility with emerging standards like Matter, which could streamline smart home device interactions and enhance user experience.

articles.title: Anthropic and the Department of Defense to advance responsible AI in defense operations
articles.summary: The U.S. Department of Defense has awarded Anthropic a two-year, $200 million contract to develop advanced AI capabilities aimed at enhancing national security. This partnership is significant as it underscores the DOD's commitment to integrating frontier AI technologies while ensuring responsible deployment, particularly in sensitive government contexts. Key next steps include collaborating with defense experts to prototype AI solutions tailored to DOD needs, addressing potential adversarial uses of AI, and fostering responsible AI adoption across the defense enterprise.

articles.title: Google swears it isn’t destroying the web with AI search
articles.summary: Google has defended its AI search features, stating that overall website traffic remains stable despite claims of declining clicks due to AI-generated summaries. This assertion is significant as it counters recent reports indicating that digital media outlets are suffering from reduced traffic, prompting layoffs and concerns about the future of online content. Moving forward, Google plans to enhance its search capabilities further with AI-curated results, which may continue to reshape user engagement and the digital publishing landscape.

articles.title: Anthropic to sign the EU Code of Practice
articles.summary: Anthropic has announced its intention to sign the European Union's General-Purpose AI Code of Practice, emphasizing its commitment to transparency, safety, and accountability in AI development. This move is significant as it aligns with the EU's efforts to harness AI's potential, projected to contribute over a trillion euros annually to the economy by the mid-2030s, while ensuring innovation and competitiveness. Key implications include the establishment of mandatory safety frameworks that will guide AI risk assessment and mitigation, alongside a collaborative approach with regulatory bodies to adapt policies as technology evolves.

articles.title: Automate security reviews with Claude Code
articles.summary: Today, Claude Code announced the launch of automated security reviews, enabling developers to identify and fix vulnerabilities directly from their terminal using the new /security-review command and a GitHub Actions integration. This is significant as it enhances code security in an era where rapid development increases the risk of vulnerabilities, allowing teams to catch issues before they reach production. Key implications include a streamlined security review process that integrates with existing workflows, promoting consistent security practices across development teams and improving overall product security.

articles.title: OpenAI teases GPT-5 launch event this Thursday
articles.summary: OpenAI is set to announce its highly anticipated GPT-5 AI model on Thursday at 10 AM PT, as hinted by a cryptic post on X. This release is significant as it follows recent indications of readiness from OpenAI and Microsoft, suggesting a major advancement in AI capabilities. Key implications include heightened competition in the AI space and potential shifts in how users interact with AI technologies, especially following the recent introduction of the free GPT-OSS model.

articles.title: Paul Smith to join Anthropic as Chief Commercial Officer
articles.summary: Anthropic has announced the appointment of Paul Smith as its first Chief Commercial Officer, effective later this year, bringing over 30 years of experience from leading tech firms like Microsoft and Salesforce. This move is significant as Anthropic experiences rapid growth in the enterprise market, with a fivefold increase in recurring revenue from its Claude AI in just two months, highlighting the increasing demand for AI solutions across industries. Key implications include enhanced commercial strategies to support businesses in their AI adoption journey, positioning Anthropic as a trusted partner in navigating the transformative landscape of AI technology.

articles.title: National security expert Richard Fontaine appointed to Anthropic’s long-term benefit trust
articles.summary: Anthropic's Long-Term Benefit Trust has appointed Richard Fontaine, CEO of the Center for a New American Security, to enhance its expertise in navigating the intersection of AI and national security. This appointment is significant as it underscores the growing importance of responsible AI development amid geopolitical risks, aligning with Anthropic's mission to ensure a safe transition through transformative AI. Moving forward, Fontaine's experience will guide the Trust in addressing the complex challenges posed by advanced AI, influencing both corporate strategy and broader societal implications.

articles.title: Call of Duty and Battlefield 6 will both require Secure Boot on Windows
articles.summary: Activision will require Call of Duty: Black Ops 7 players on PC to enable Trusted Platform Module (TPM) 2.0 and Secure Boot to enhance anti-cheat measures, though these features won't be enforced until the game's release later this year. The company emphasizes that while these hardware-level protections are crucial for combating cheaters, they should not affect in-game performance, and players are encouraged to adopt two-factor authentication, which may become mandatory in the future.

articles.title: I tested Grok’s Valentine sex chatbot and it (mostly) behaved
articles.summary: The article explores the release of Valentine, Grok's new AI companion designed for adult interactions, highlighting its limitations in conversation and responsiveness compared to its predecessor, Ani. The author notes concerns about the AI's biases, the unsettling default microphone setting, and its cautious approach to sexual topics, which raises questions about consent and the nature of AI interactions in adult contexts.
